Jan 2, 2014

Seawolves Face Toughest Test Of The Year At VCU

Tipoff: Friday, 9pm

Location: Siegel Center on the campus of Virginia Commonwealth University, Richmond, VA

After almost two weeks off, the Seawolves start the New Year with arguably their toughest test this season: a road matchup against Atlantic-10 powerhouse Virginia Commonwealth. This is the first-ever meeting between the two teams and both are looking for their fourth straight win.

For those who don’t know about VCU, the Rams reemerged on the national stage over the past few years starting with a miraculous run to the 2011 Final Four as the #11 seed, tying a record as the lowest seed to make a run that deep. They joined the A-10 last year and earned their third straight NCAA berth, making it to the third round.

The VCU program is one built on recruitment and development with the big-picture in mind. Sound familiar? Stony Brook has been going down the same path during the Steve Pikiell era, so we can only hope that the Seawolves will be able to emulate some of VCU’s success in the coming years.

The Rams were nationally ranked earlier this season, but losses to Florida St. and Northern Iowa knocked them out of the top-25. They have been on a roll lately with three straight wins by 15 points or more, and their trademark pressure defense is in top form as they held all three opponents to under 60 points. In its most recent win, a 69–50 trouncing of Boston College, VCU’s “HAVOC” defense was on full display as the Rams scored 22 points off 23 turnovers. They are averaging 20.4 turnovers forced per game this year.

VCU’s depth is incredible this year as five Rams average 8.0 points or more, but no player averages more than 29 minutes per game. Junior shooting guard Treveon Graham leads the way with 15.4 points per game. Senior big man Juvonte Reddic is averaging 11.7 points on 59% shooting to go with 7.5 rebounds.

The Seawolves are coming into this game with a ton of momentum, but this will be a tough one for them. A different player has led Stony Brook in scoring over the last three games. Sophomore Jameel Warney has continued his dominance, averaging 17 points and nine rebounds over his last two games to earn America East Co-Player of the Week honors last week. He is ranked fifth in the nation in field goal percentage (66.1%).

Dave Coley, who scored his 1,000th point last game, is returning to form as he has reached double figures in eight of the last nine games. Carson Puriefoy continues to play exceptionally well off the bench and ranks third on the team in scoring with 12.2 points per game.

Stony Brook will have to play efficiently to pull off the upset tomorrow. Anthony Jackson, Coley and Puriefoy all have to play smart and limit their turnovers. Warney will have to continue to be consistent on the inside. Scott King, Rayshaun McGrew and Chris Braley all have to give strong contributions off the bench. All hands on deck! This is a huge opportunity for the Seawolves to prove something to fans, critics, the RPI gods and, most importantly, themselves.

Keys to the Game

Break the press. Stony Brook has dealt with full-court pressure at times throughout this season, but nothing like the one VCU will play. The Rams will press for the entire 40 minutes, testing the Seawolves’ stamina and desire to win. The main facet of the press is that it can take the heart out of a team; players can get tired of dealing with it and feel like giving up. The Seawolves will have to remain consistent in their approach to breaking VCU’s pressure. Jackson, Coley, Puriefoy and Ahmad Walker will be relied on heavily throughout the game.

Go early, go often. If Stony Brook is able to break VCU’s full-court press, there could be ample opportunities to get some easy shots. Puriefoy is the fastest player on the team so he needs to take every opportunity he has to get to the rim for a layup, and the rest of the guards will have to follow suit. Even if they can’t finish, they should at the very least be able to draw some fouls. This will in-turn put pressure on the Rams and force them to re-think their defensive strategy.

Projected Starting Lineup

#4 G Anthony Jackson
#5 G Dave Coley
#3 G Ahmad Walker
#20 F Jameel Warney
#22 F Eric McAlister

Prediction

Stony Brook has been preparing for this game for almost two weeks. Knowing the coaching staff, they most likely put the players through thorough film sessions and developed a strategy to combat VCU’s pressure. If the Seawolves can play efficiently, they might just be able to pull off the upset.

Seawolves 67, VCU 62
